title: house of lords abolished poll house of lords brexit vote
story: More than 2,700 readers have voted in the Express.co.uk poll as of 10.40pm, with almost all backing a move to for the upper house of UK parliament to be abolished.And just four percent of readers polled said they wanted to keep the House of Lords which this week has threatened to derail Brexit.One Express.co.uk reader said: &ldquoLet&rsquos have a referendum on abolishing the House of Lords now.&rdquoAnother added: &ldquoIt&rsquos time for this den of unelected parasites (the Lords) to go.&ldquoThey have always served their own greed.&rdquoA petition calling for the House of Lords to be scrapped and replaced with a new elected body hit 100,000 votes earlier this year potentially triggering a Commons debate.GETTYA massive 96 percent of Express readers have voted to abolish the House of Lords                Theresa May faces ANOTHER Brexit customs union showdown with rebels                Farage hits out at Boris Johnson and Gove for 'Brexit betrayal'But Whitehall said the Government recognises the importance of House of Lords reform but that the issue was not a priority in this Parliament.The response added: Where there are further measures that can command consensus from across the House, the Government would welcome working with peers to look at how to take them forward.The resounding result comes after Prime Minister Theresa May suffered a bruising setback to her Brexit plans in a crunch House of Lords vote on Wednesday evening, with Lords voting 348 to 225 in favour of changing the EU Withdrawal Bill legislation.A cross-party alliance of Lords, including Tory rebels, put forward an amendment to the Bill in a move that could leave the door open for Britain to remain in the customs union, despite the Prime Minister ruling it out.If such a move were to be forced, it would destroy Britain&rsquos chances of being able to strike post-Brexit trade deals with several countries across the world, including the US and Australia.GETTYMichael Gove rejected suggestions Britain could remain in the customs unionSpeaking on the BBC&rsquos Today programme, Environment Secretary and leading Brexiteer Michael Gove rejected suggestions Britain would be forced to back down and remain in the customs union.&ldquoI listened with interest to some of the contributions to the debate but I think that it&rsquos important to always listen to what the House of Lords says.&ldquoBut the House of Commons has been very clear. The British people were very clear in the referendum.&ldquoWe are leaving the European Union. Leaving the European Union also means taking back control of our borders and our trade.Mr Gove added: &ldquoBeing able to sign our own free trade deals is a compelling and persuasive one.&ldquoI know that when that case is put to the House of Commons it will rally Conservative MPs and others behind it.&ldquoA case endorsed by 17.4 million people in the referendum and one the Government has pledged to honour.&rdquoLabour&rsquos Yvette Cooper and Tory Nicky Morgan have also now drafted a motion that urges Mrs May to include an &ldquoeffective customs union&rdquo in her Brexit negotiations.Senior Tories fear the latest reverse in the House of Lords could be the start of a series of defeats during the Lords Report Stage of the legislation, with a hardcore group of Remain-backing having tabled dozens more amendments.Analysis by the Change Britain pressure group has revealed that 10 fanatical Remain-backing peers have proposed a total of 338 amendments aimed at frustrating or even reversing the country&rsquos departure from the EU.The research from the group, which wants a full break with Brussels, showed that Labour peer Lord Judd had tabled a massive 62 amendments to the EU Withdrawal Bill, which is designed to transfer EU law into the UK to ensure a smooth Brexit process.Fellow Labour peer Lord Adonis had tabled 59 amendments while Lib Dem Lord Wallace of Tankerness was responsible for 49 of them.

title: brexit news eu uk meps guy verhofstadt european parliament
story: However, MEPs from across the political spectrum with eurosceptic and pro-European politicians have joined up to build a consensus that will ultimately protect the European Union as well as their own agendas.Nigel Farage&rsquos EFDD group houses 45 MEPs who are critical of the EU in their own different ways, while Parliament&rsquos largest group the EPP has 219 representatives wholeheartedly behind the Brussels project &ndash including two British Remainers who left their fellow Conservatives to rejoin the EPP in 2017.While Jean-Claude Juncker&rsquos European Commission is the body handling Brexit negotiations on behalf of the EU, MEPs in Parliament will vote on recommendations of how they see Brexit progressing.Their views will remain important as they will have a decisive say on the final agreement between the EU and UK in the shape of a Parliament-wide vote.But what do different MEPs from across the European Parliament actually want from Brexit and how will their opinions shape the UK&rsquos orce from Brussels?GETTYMEPs from across the political spectrum are ided over Brexit                Hartley-Brewer in brutal Lord Adonis slap down after Lords Brexit vote                IDS explains why EU single market bad for UK in fiery Lords crackdownGETTYHans Olaf-Henkel says the UK has common sense and wants to offer a solution to keep us in the EUHans-Olaf Henkel, Germany, European Conservative and Reformist Group.This senior MEP sits alongside the majority of the EU Parliament&rsquos British Conservative politicians, and has a distinct view on how Brexit should pan out.Mr Henkel, one of Parliament&rsquos anti-federalists, is a critic of Brexit but does not pin the blame on the UK for the decision.The German argues that key EU players Michel Barnier and Guy Verhofstadt did not help the cause with their criticism of the Brexit campaign.He is now leading a one-man crusade to offer Britain a new EU deal in the hope Westminster will opt to reverse the Brexit decision and rejoin the EU.Jean-Claude Juncker greets colleagues with kisses and slaps 1 of 16Mr Henkel told Express.co.uk: &ldquoFor me, Britain is the last country with common sense in the European Union, when Britain leaves we&rsquore losing an ally for reasonability.&rdquoHe added: &ldquoThe values the British stand for are values Europe should stand for.&ldquoYou like competitiveness, they like harmonisation. You like ersity, they like equality. You like self-responsibility for a country&rsquos state of bank debts, they want to socialise them.&ldquoThe whole EU, itself, is becoming over time a much less attractive, competitive place. If we lose Britain we are in a really bad shape.&rdquoBecause of this, Mr Henkel believes it is time the EU make &ldquoBritain a new offer, an offer that Britain can&rsquot refuse, an offer that gives Britain what they always wanted&rdquo.GETTYGabriele Zimmer is on the Brexit Steering Group and says the EU needs to understand the Brexit voteGabriele Zimmer, Germany, Confederal Group of the European United Left &ndash Nordic Green LeftMrs Zimmer is of the European Parliament&rsquos most influential MEPs when it comes to Brexit because of the German&rsquos position on the Brexit Steering Group.As one of the Steering Group&rsquos members, Mrs Zimmer has some of the biggest say when it comes to shaping the European Parliament&rsquos Brexit policy.Using her ties to the left, Mrs Zimmer hopes to create a socially driven Brexit which is in the interest of citizens both in Britain and in the remaining EU27.Speaking to Express.co.uk, the German insisted her movement would never seek to punish Britain for Brexit.She said: &ldquoBetween the different political groups we have different positions to the EU and different positions to the referendum, or in which way we should react to the referendum.&ldquoWe as the left, our position is we have to think about the reasons why the majority of the voters decided for a Brexit &ndash why they think the European Union would be reason for criticism of their daily lives and the conditions they have.&ldquoI&rsquom not sharing a position to say the people in the 27 other member states they see the consequences and the impact of the Brexit on the daily lives for people in Great Britain &ndash and that&rsquos why they remain in the European Union, I don&rsquot think this is a good approach.&ldquoI think we have to do more for our common solidarity inside the Union &ndash for a better Union, a more social Union, for more democracy inside the Union. That is the way we have to go and we have to do a lot to change things here in the Union.&ldquoThat&rsquos why my group are saying we don&rsquot want to punish Britain for their decision to leave the EU.&rdquoMrs Zimmer maintains her movement are bringing both the welfare of EU and British citizens to the Steering Group when discussing Brexit.REUTERSGuy Verhofstadt is an outspoken critic of BrexitGuy Verhofstadt, Belgium, Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for EuropeThe former Belgian prime minister is the chairman of the European Parliament&rsquos Brexit Steering Group and one of the most outspoken critics of the orce.With an influential role, he uses his position in Parliament to strike a deal which he sees will benefit the EU and its remaining member states.An advocate for the rights of EU citizens who wish to remain in Britain after Brexit, Mr Verhofstadt has used the Windrush case to demand a series of meeting with the British Home Office to ensure EU citizens&rsquo rights are respected as per the agreement in Phase One of negotiations.Mr Verhofstadt warned EU citizens could face a &ldquobureaucratic nightmare&rdquo after Brexit in the wake of the UK&rsquos handling of the Windrush generation &ndash immigrants who moved from the Caribbean to Britain over 50 years ago.Despite being legally entitled to live in the UK, the Windrush generation have suffered difficulties when finding work and accessing benefits and healthcare in the UK.The Belgian MEP told Parliament: &ldquoCertainly after the Windrush scandal in Britain, we want to be sure the same is not happening to our European citizens and that there is no bureaucratic nightmare there.&rdquoGETTYFlorian Philippot is an ally of Nigel Farage who is working for Frexit, tooFlorian Philippot, France, Europe of Freedom and Direct DemocracyAn ally of leading Brexiteer Nigel Farage, Mr Philippot is a critic of the EU and attempts to create a more integrated Union.When French President Emmanuel Macron presented his plans to reform the bloc, Mr Philippot presented one of the only challenges to his countryman.He denounced the French President for wanting a EU that disregards the risk of terrorism and migration.Mr Philippot added: &ldquoThe British people, whether you like it or not, sovereignly voted in favour of independence and freedom.&ldquoThe European Union is the past.&rdquoAnd in one final blow, he declared: &ldquoLong live Frexit and long live a free France.&rdquoGETTYPhilippe Lamberts is a pro-European and says we can't keep the Good Friday Agreement and have BrexitPhilippe Lamberts, Belgium, Group of the Greens &ndash European Free AllianceThe Belgian MEP is another member of the Brexit Steering Group and a pro-European politician.Using his position he has been seeking protection of the Good Friday Agreement and the prevention of a hard border emerging on the island of Ireland.Mr Lamberts has even gone as far to suggest the Irish border question could see Britain one day rejoin the European Union.He believes Theresa May&rsquos commitment to preventing a hard border leaves the British Prime Minister with little choice but to consider EU membership for her country once again.Mr Lambert&rsquos said: &ldquoIf &ndash and it&rsquos a big if &ndash the UK wants to keep the Good Friday Agreement, the only satisfactory option is full EU membership.&ldquoThat is the only logical conclusion.&rdquo

title: Brexit news Australia trade deal customs union eu uk MPs julie bishop
story: GETTYJulie Bishop has hit out at Remain MPsThe country&rsquos foreign minister Julie Bishop hit out at Remainer politicians for their plot to keep Britain shackled to the bloc after Brexit, thus thwarting her vision for &ldquoenormous opportunities for more trade and investment&rdquo with Australia.She warned: &ldquoThe opportunity for us to enter a free trade agreement with the UK standing alone would not be achievable&rdquo, referencing rebel MPs' plot to keep Britain chained to EU tariffs after Brexit in next week&rsquos crucial vote.It comes after Singapore offered a rapid agreement Britain in an attempt to prevent a &ldquohard stop&rdquo after Brexit.The Sun reported Singapore&rsquos super-rich foreign minister Vivian Balakrishnan was desperate for a &ldquocontinuity arrangement&rdquo as soon as Britain leaves the EU.GETTYNicky Morgan is one of the Conservative MPs going against Theresa May Mr Balakrishnan said: &ldquoIn due time we can look to upgrade, modify, improve the agreement but it is very important that in this transition period not to have a hard stop.&rdquoAustralia&rsquos dire warning to Theresa May follows news of a potential leadership battle should the PM row back on her promise and keeps Britain in the EU customs union after the UK leaves the bloc.According to the Times, The PM has been warned that a concession to keep Britain in the 28-member customs union will prompt a flood of no-confidence letters from Brexitbacking MPs, which would likely trigger a leadership challenge.One Conservative backbencher said: &ldquoIf there's a cave-in on the customs union, I think there will be a leadership challenge.&rdquoUp to 48 letters are required for a leadership battle, according to Conservative Party rules.Mrs May had insisted Britain will leave the EU customs market following Brexit to prompt trade deals across the globe.GETTYPROSIT PHOTOTalks have sparked a growing sense of panic and anger in Brussels, Dublin, Belfast and WestminsterYesterday, the EU blasted every single Irish border proposal, sparking fears Brexit talks are on the brink of collapse.The question of how Britain can balance an open Irish border while pulling Northern Ireland from the customs union and single market appeared to be the one issue which could bring the Brexit process screeching to a halt.Leaders in Dublin, Belfast and Brussels spent much of the lead-up to the June 2016 referendum issuing increasingly desperate warnings about the Irish border, which has been &lsquoinvisible&rsquo and free of customs and police checks since the 1990s.Adding more controversy and confusion is the DUP, who prop up Mrs May&rsquos minority government.Leader Arlene Foster said she will not accept anything other than Northern Ireland leaving the EU on the same terms as England, Wales and Scotland, ruling out a solution which would see the Republic and Northern Ireland become economically aligned.GETTYMrs May had insisted Britain will leave the EU customs market following BrexitTalks continue - albeit with a growing sense of panic and anger in Brussels, Dublin, Belfast and Westminster.Today, the PM is meeting with Australian Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull.Yesterday, The Commonwealth Heads of Government met at Windsor Castle where they discussed whether Prince Charles should succeed the Queen as head of the 53-nation alliance.

title: The queen birthday queen elizabeth turns 92 today
story: Elizabeth II has long remained committed to her duty to the nation since she took to the throne in 1952.But young Elizabeth was never meant to be monarch &ndash she was born the daughter of the second son of King George V.But her uncle Edward VIII&rsquos abdication changed the course of history when he stepped down from the throne to marry the woman he loved, pushing his brother - Elizabeth&rsquos father King George V - into the spotlight, which eventually led her to become the Queen.And on her 21st birthday, Elizabeth II pledged to serve the country for her whole life.GETTY The Queen is celebrating her 92nd birthday today. title: London marathon route map 2018 where can you watch the marathon
story: GETTYLondon marathon route map 2018: Where can you watch the marathon and where do the runners go? Runners across the country have got two weeks left to prepare for one of the biggest races in the UK.The 38th annual footrace is kicking off before 10am on Sunday 22, with the Queen starting the race from Windsor.It is the first time the Queen has taken an active role in the starting of the race, the third time a Royal has been involved.Around 39,000 people are expected to take part in this year&rsquos event, with millions more watching the race across the country.With TV live coverage showing every step, tens of thousands of supporters make their way to the capital to show their support in person.The 26.2-mile route is normally lined with thousands of watchers, but where can you watch the marathon?                Queen to officially start London Marathon 2018 for the first time                 London Marathon running tips: Top trick to run fasterWhere do the runners go?The 26.2-mile stretch begins in Blackheath and finishes on the Mall, just outside the doors of Buckingham Palace.The track goes east from Blackheath through Woolwich for three miles before cutting west across&nbsp Cutty Sark in Greenwich.Along Tower Bridge the runners go, before it then runs around the Isle of Dogs and through Canary Wharf and then turning back on itself towards London Bridge.Mile 23 snakes back across London Bridge, Embankment and Parliament Square before rounding Birdcage Walk and ending up on the Royal Doorstep around St James&rsquo Park and the Horse Guards Palace.GETTYWhere are the best places to come and watch the London Marathon?Where can you watch the London Marathon?The&nbsp26 mile&nbsptrack is usually packed with supporters but there are better places to&nbspgo to&nbspensure you get the best view.It is not advised to go to the start of the race in Blackheath. This area is for runners only and does not hold anywhere for spectators.You are unlikely to see much at this point anyway.Around the three-mile mark, Woolwich Arsenal is a great place to get an early look-in.On the DLR, spectators can expect a short walk from the station to get to the river and cheer on the runners.GETTYWhere can you watch the London Marathon?Canada Water is the next best place taking the race. Sitting on the eight-11-mile point, the Surrey Quays&nbspis&nbspa popular place to stand and watch, so be wary.Runners should be expected to reach this point by roughly 10-11:10am.One of the most popular locations is on London Bridge, one of the most iconic landmarks in London.Viewers get to London Bridge VERY early, to lockdown prime locations, so only go here if you are willing to wait around.The embankment&nbspis also a good place to camp up, with runners covering the length of the river and winding down towards the&nbspfinish line.This section is always very busy so make sure you get there early or have a good exit-plan.Express Sport brings you all the best snaps of the most ridiculous and hilarious costumes from the 2017 London Marathon                    PA1 of 9There were some brilliant and not so brilliant costumes at the London Marathon!Where to avoidWestminster is a notoriously busy section of the track so it is advised to&nbspavoid&nbspthis area unless you get there very early.Cutty Sark is also a hotly contested area, so make sure to keep away from these sections.Public transport is free for runners but not for spectators, so make sure you plan your route carefully to avoid delays.London is normally very busy but is much worse during the marathon, so expect busy buses and tube trains.Extra services are on to make life easier for locals and spectators.TV coverageLive coverage on will be on BBC One, BBC iPlayer, and the&nbspBBC&nbspSport&nbspwebsite.Expert commentary will be available on the Red Button, as the runners complete the race.Live coverage of the Queen pushing the start button - the first time she has ever done so - at&nbsp10am&nbspsharp from the grounds of Windsor Castle will be streamed onto the big screens on the start line in Blackheath.

title: denise gallagher dyslexic grandmother delighted reading grandchildren
story: SWNSDyslexic Denise Gallagher learned to read so she could have storytime with her grandkidsAs a child she was branded &ldquostupid&rdquo and deliberately misbehaved to be thrown out of class and avoid the humiliation of trying to read out loud. She spent years unable to go shopping and even refused to eat at restaurants for fear of not being able to read the menu.Now she can enjoy snuggling up with Ethan, six, and Blake, nine, and reading them bedtime tales. Denise said: &ldquoThey have always understood Nana cannot read but I just got fed up of saying, &lsquoAsk Grandad&rsquo.&ldquoI&rsquove always felt so guilty that I didn&rsquot have the courage and determination to learn and read to my own kids but my children don&rsquot blame me.&ldquoNow the grandchildren are getting fed up with me reading to them all the time!&rdquo&nbsp                Holly Willoughby makes shock revelation about Phillip Schofield                Swimming helped me cope with dyslexia, says Olympian Duncan GoodhewSWNSAt school no-one spotted Denise's dyslexiaSWNSDenise Gallagher had always masked her illiteracyDenise, from Wigan, finally conquered her dyslexia thanks to ITV show This Time Next Year, hosted by Davina McCall. Working with teachers on the show, she has learned to read to a basic standard within 12 months.The Wizard Of Oz and The Railway Children are among the classics with which she now delights her grandkids.She said: &ldquoThere was nothing for dyslexic people when I was at school, people just thought you were thick.&ldquoI have struggled all my life with basic things like going shopping. It&rsquos been like that all my life but I just got on with it. Nowadays it&rsquos much worse because everything is email or online.&rdquoAfter leaving school Denise found jobs that masked her illiteracy &ndash as a cleaner or sewing machinist.It was while finding work 30 years ago with disability specialist Remploy that she met her husband Michael, 64. Michael, who is deaf, learned from a young age to lip read, which is how the couple communicate. She said: &ldquoPart of the reason I wanted to learn to read is to do sign language. You have to be able to read and spell to do that.&rdquo

story: STEVE REIGATECharley Hall, 19, in Southsea, Hampshire, yesterdayAnd the mini-heatwave continues with a sweltering start to the weekend.Meteorologist John West said today would be a mixed day with plenty of sunshine early on, although patchy showers and thunderstorms are expected to hit south-west England and Wales in the afternoon and evening.St James's Park in London reached 78.9F yesterday - 18 degrees above April averages.But tomorrow, cooler, fresher air will start to work its way in and we should expect a return to changeable springtime weather next week. But he echoed warnings that this year's London Marathon could be a hot and humid affair, with highs of around 71F.The 40,000 runners attempting the 26.2-mile course have been warned to go at a slower pace, use extra ice, water and showers provided and think carefully about wearing fancy dress costumes.The hottest UK April temperature in almost 70 years was recorded on Thursday when the mercury hit 84F in St James's Park, central London.

title: IVF twins hen s egg seven years
story: PHSarah and Tony Elder pictured on holiday with their &lsquomiracle&rsquo twins, aged fourSarah Elder thought she would never become a mother after trying for seven years to fall pregnant. Archie and Scarlett were born after their parents spent more than &pound25,000 on failed fertility treatment.Mrs Elder, 42, who lives with landscaper husband Tony, 49, in the Isle of Man, said: I can't believe I finally have my twins, it really does seem like a miracle.It has taken so many years of trying and now we are all a family at last. And it's all thanks to the yolk of a hen egg. It seems unbelievable.The couple started trying for a family in 2006 but it wasn't a success. Four years later, they decided to try a course of fertility treatment.                'I feel exploited' Mum speaks out as IVF clinics accused of ignoring                Baby born FOUR YEARS after his parents died in a car crashUKTwins Archie, left, and Scarlett were born after seven years of treatmentThey underwent their first course of IVF in 2010 but that failed and the couple were devastated. Mrs Elder said: We had really thought the treatment would work straight away, so to have found out it had failed was heartbreaking.But we refused to give up hope - we were desperate to become parents so we knew we would just keep trying.The couple had another attempt and Mrs Elder did fall pregnant, but she miscarried the baby a few weeks later.Doctors then recommended trying a different technique. So for the seventh course of fertility treatment, Mrs Elder had an intravenous treatment called intralipid infusion, which involves using yolk from a hen's egg.It works by fatty acids in the egg reducing the number of killer cells in the immune system.Sarah, who works as head of finance and operational services for Hospice Isle of Man, said: I'd never heard of using egg yolk to try and have a baby before, but I was willing to try anything. We'd been trying for a baby for seven years and I didn't know how much more we could both take. We decided we would have one last treatment - it was going to be our last chance.Her pregnancy went smoothly and the twins, who are non-identical as they have each been conceived with a different egg, arrived in November 2013, Scarlett weighing 7lb, and Archie the biggest at 7lb 7oz.Mrs Elder added: It was the most amazing feeling when we finally held them in our arms. After a seven-year battle, we were finally a mum and dad at last.And the four-year-old twins are healthy and happy, said mum.

story: GETTYLondon Marathon 2018: Last minute preparations &ndash How to prepare the day before a marathonThe London Marathon will take place tomorrow with thousands of runners looking to complete the gruelling 26.2-mile course through the capital.&nbspRunners up and down the country have spent months sticking to strict diets and tough training to prepare to take on the challenge.&nbspHere is how you can prepare for the marathon 24 hours before.&nbsp                London Marathon 2018: Which celebrities are running in this year&rsquos ... The amount of time required varies between runners, so it's helpful to try your pre-race meal timing in tune-up races prior to the marathon.&nbsp&ldquoFor most runners, eating three to four hours in advance is enough time to get the benefits of a small meal without experiencing digestive distress out on the course.&ldquoTry to find a place to lie down and relax to pass the time. title: eu news debt euro zone angela merkel germany liable
story: Mrs Merkel, who has abandoned her opposition to a common European deposit insurance aimed at offering protection across the bloc, told reporters at a press conference in Berlin that her countrymen will be liable in the event of it hitting the rocks.Speaking alongside French President Emmanuel Macron, she said: We are also ready to create a joint deposit insurance system in perhaps not the immediate, but more distant future.&nbsp&ldquoWe do want liability and risks to be kept together.&rdquo&nbspMrs Merkel stressed she was very optimistic that the banking union, involving the transfer of banking policy from the national to the EU level in several member states, could be completed.&nbspGETTYGerman Chancellor Angela Merkel and French President Emmanuel Macron in Berlin                European Central Bank publishes fresh guidelines for euro banks                 France and Germany vow to LEAD Eurozone reforms But behind the scenes, there is ongoing debate about how far bad loans from banks need to be reduced before European solidarity can be applied to financial institutions in need.Mrs Merkel, who agreed to the banking union in March, said she wants to see a further reduction of the debts and risks of national banks in the EU states.&nbspAt the time she said Germany had always been willing to give up sovereignty, if things could be better regulated by Europe.Her country was also willing to help stabilise the Euro and was prepared for joint euro debt, she added.Angela Merkel has served as German Chancellor since 2005 and Leader of the Christian Democratic Union since 2000. We take a look at her political career in pictures.                    AFPGetty Images1 of 83Angela Merkel through the years The reduction of bad loans is progressing slowly in Europe.&nbspItaly reported the sale of billions of financial investors before its general election in March - but this represents just a fraction of the total of bad loans.German banks are feeling the pressure, with NordLB working hard to solve its capital problem after the takeover of the ailing Bremer Landesbank.Mrs Merkel and Mr Macron said the EU should accept a comprehensive package of reforms in June in areas such as the euro-monetary union and asylum and foreign policy.GETTYGerman banks including NordLb, based in Frankfurt, are feeling the pressureThe possibility of an EU-wide finance minister, and a Eurozone budget have also been floated.She added: &rdquoWe agree that the Eurozone is not yet sufficiently crisis-proof.We bring in some other aspects, but I believe that the sum of our proposals will lead to a good result at the end.&rdquo&nbspThe pair insisted that by June, they wanted to develop a common position.

story: Britain is leaving the bloc in March 2019, followed by a two-year Brexit transition period of around two years.But Angela Merkel has been warned the move could cause havoc for Germany&rsquos finances and leave Germany a &ldquocountry where poverty and misery prevail&rdquo.Author and economics writer G&uumlnter Hannich cited research by the European Committee of the Regions showing 41 out of 50 German regions will see industry, craft and skilled trades under serious pressure from the loss of Britain.Those regions include Hamburg, Berlin, Cologne, Darmstadt, Dusseldorf and the western Ruhr area.GETTYGermany could be hit by Brexit                Brexit news: Polish men hope to trademark brand Brexit for drinks firm                'EU is using Ireland to trap UK inside bloc!' Tory MEP's SHOCK warningWriting for German website GeVestor said: &ldquoThis makes Germany, along with Ireland, the country that will suffer the most from Brexit.&ldquoI can tell you one thing: this event will have massive consequences for us and our everyday lives.&rdquoThe author, who has regularly predicted the Euro&rsquos collapse, said Germany&rsquos dependence on exports meant it was particularly vulnerable to any downturn in the worldwide economy or Britain&rsquos fortunes.Mr Hannich said: &ldquoBetween 16 and 17.5 percent of economic output in the manufacturing sector is affected by Brexit.GETTYAngela Merkel could face a Brexit nightmare&ldquoThis is another indication that our upswing will not continue much longer. If Britain leaves the EU, it will have a massive impact on our economy.&ldquoSince the local upswing is largely based on exports, this alone will be a significant setback.&ldquoIf, as I expect, there will be a worldwide new financial crisis, then the alleged &lsquoeconomic miracle country&rsquo will very quickly become a country where poverty and misery prevail.&ldquoI assume that the next crisis will hit Germany hardest because of its one-sided dependence on exports.&ldquoGETTYThe Brexit vote could cause havoc in the EUThis month, European Committee of the Regions chairman Karl-Heinz Lambertz called for Germany to do more in a bid to minimise the impact on regions.Mr Lambertz said: Given their close ties, the report suggests that German regions could be among the countries most seriously affected by the UK's exit from the EU.&rdquoHe called for a trade agreement between the UK and remaining EU members to allow free movement of goods and minimise tariffs.Mr Lambertz said, with the help of the EU's regional investment policy, every effort must be made to minimise the impact on the regions.GETTYManufacturing could be hit when the UK leavesGerman MEP Hans-Olaf Henkel has also warned Brexit is a &ldquolose-lose&rdquo situation for his country and will hit thousands of jobs in Angela Merkel&rsquos nation.He said, while people are &ldquorealising the disadvantages of Brexit&rdquo, political leaders on the continent think it is only going to cause problems in the UK.(Additional reporting by Monika Pallenberg)

title: Ku Klux Klan How black cop infiltrated the Klan
story: PHDICING WITH DEATH: Ron Stallworth as a Colorado Springs policeman in 1979As crosses burned on front lawns and KKK killers terrorised blacks he risked his life to become a Klan chapter chief.Stallworth won the trust of the organisation's Grand Wizard David Duke while secretly thwarting the Klan's plans for bombings, armed assaults and racial attacks. It was all in a day's work for the detective except for one small detail: Ron Stallworth is black.His extraordinary penetration of the violent heart of America's hardcore racists is told in film director Spike Lee's new thriller BlacKkKlansman, just announced as an official American entry in the Cannes Film Festival and coming to British screens later this year.                Ku Klux Klan leader warns 'there will be more violence'                 ANGER student who dressed as KKK member will participate in boat racePHRon Stallworth&rsquos Ku Klux Klan membership cardIt was extremely dangerous to be a black man in the KKK, admits Stallworth, aged 65, in an exclusive interview with the Daily Express.If I'd been exposed it could have all gone horribly wrong. The Klansmen were armed and there was always a peril.Stallworth, who has received numerous death threats since revealing how he fooled the Klan, was an undercover detective in Colorado Springs, Colorado - the city's first black officer - when he infiltrated the group.It was 1979, a year when the Klan killed five protesters in North Carolina and hung nooses from trees as threats across the Deep South.Stallworth was working in criminal intelligence and organised crime when he spotted a newspaper ad seeking members for a new KKK chapter.I wrote to the PO Box posing as a white racist.He explained that he hated blacks, Jews, Hiics, Chinese, Japanese, Italians - anyone who wasn't pure Aryan.I used every racial slur I knew to sound like one of them, he says.I gave them an untraceable phone number in my office but I wasn't thinking straight and used my real name, which could have been disastrous if they were any smarter but the Klan weren't the brightest bulbs in the socket.ALAMYFULL OF HATE: KKK Grand Wizard David Duke in 1978A week later a Klan organiser phoned, asking why Stallworth wanted to join.I said my sister is dating a n***** and every time he puts his filthy hands on her white body it makes me mad. And I want to stop that happening again.BUT when Stallworth didn't hear back he went straight to the top.I phoned the KKK Grand Wizard David Duke in Louisiana and asked why my membership was being delayed. He said my application was on his desk and promised to deal with it personally.It was the first of many conversations with David Duke. We talked about his family, the weather and about his political ambitions.Once I asked him, 'How do you know that you're not speaking with a n***** who's pretending to be white just to fool you?' He said, 'N****** don't talk like white folk. We say How are you but a n***** says, How are-a you. It gives them away.'I couldn't help laughing. Sometimes my sergeant would listen to me spouting racial slurs, saying how much I hated n****** and he would laugh so hard he had to leave the room.But it was no laughing matter when the KKK wanted to meet their new recruit.They wanted to know what I looked like so I described one of my fellow undercover detectives, whom I'll call 'Chuck' to protect his identity.In Spike Lee's movie Chuck is played by Star Wars' nefarious Adam Driver.When it came to meetings I'd send Chuck and briefed him on all the phone calls and plans we had made. Then after meeting the Klan posing as Stallworth he would tell me what happened.For more than seven months we infiltrated the local Klan, exposing their criminal plans.Corbis  GettyStallworth's investigation ended when he was asked to head the local Klan chapterThere were two gay bars in town that they wanted to bomb and the Klan had military members with explosives experience so the threat was real.Two Klansmen were working for NORAD monitoring US air space for missile attacks. I contacted the Pentagon and the next day they were reassigned to a posting near the North Pole.The Klan wanted to steal assault weapons from the nearby US army base at Fort Carson to use in attacks but I made sure that we talked about it so long that nothing got done.They planned three cross burnings but I was able to secretly call in so many uniform police cars to each location that it scared the Klan off. Most of their criminal plans were thwarted by their own incompetence.But he pushed his luck to the limit when David Duke visited Colorado Springs and Stallworth was assigned as the Grand Wizard's police bodyguard.On the outside I was cool but on the inside I was sweating bullets, he says.I was worried that Duke would recognise my voice but he never made the connection. When we met I told him, 'I don't agree with your political philosophy but I've been assigned to keep you safe and I will do that.'He shook my hand and I asked if I could be photographed with him. When I put my arm on Duke's shoulders he angrily brushed it off but just as the photograph was taken I put my arm back on his shoulder.Duke lurched for the camera but I grabbed it first. As he tried to snatch it away I told him, 'If you touch me that's assault on a police officer, with a five-year sentence.' He and about 20 Klansman stared me down but I lived to keep the photograph - sadly now lost.The undercover investigation ended when Stallworth was asked to accept leadership of the local Klan chapter.They said I had proven a loyal and capable Klansman, he laughs.But my police chief said we had to end the operation because we might be bordering on entrapment. That night the Klan burned a cross on a lawn in Colorado Springs and I wasn't there to stop it.Stallworth still has his red KKK membership card signed by Duke - It's in my wallet - and his framed certificate of membership.But he never received his white hood: The police department refused to approve the expense.When he penned his memoir Black Klansman, due to be published in the UK this year, the Klan turned on him.The FBI warned me that there were eight pages of online threats, people wanting to lynch me.Stallworth is now retired and living in El Paso, Texas, with his wife Patsy and served as a consultant on the movie.I hope it alerts people to the continuing danger of the Klan, he says. The KKK is still active across America and there is always the potential for them to strike at me if this film makes me a target.To pre-order Black Klansman by Ron Stallworth, published by Century Publishing at &pound12.99 on June 5, call the Express Bookshop with your debitcredit card on 01872 562310 or order online at expressbookshop.co.uk UK delivery is free.
